clinical_study.brief_title: Brief Interventions for Short-Term Suicide Risk Reduction in Military Populations
clinical_study.official_title: Brief Interventions for Short-Term Suicide Risk Reduction in Military Populations

collaborator.agency: The University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of the proposed study is to identify the most effective brief interventions for reducing short-term risk for suicide attempts in "real world" military triage settings, and to identify potential mechanisms of change underlying the interventions' impact on subsequent suicide attempts. We will randomize 360 patients to one of three commonly-used crisis interventions delivered as routine care in the mental health triage system: (1) Treatment As Usual (TAU); (2) Crisis Response Plan (CRP); or (3) Enhanced Crisis Response Plan with Reasons For Living (E-CRP). The following hypotheses will be tested:
1. The enhanced crisis response plan (E-CRP) intervention will contribute to significantly decreased risk for suicide attempts and hospitalization during follow-up relative to the crisis response plan alone (CRP) and treatment as usual (TAU).
2. The E-CRP intervention will contribute to greater ambivalence about suicide and faster recall of reasons for living relative to the CRP and TAU interventions.
3. Greater ambivalence about suicide and faster recall of reasons for living will mediate the relationship between intervention and reduced risk for suicide attempt during follow-up.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.description: The SASII is a valid and reliable clinician-administered interview for categorizing suicide-related and self-injurious behaviors.

Psychiatric hospitalization will be measured both as a dichotomized variable (i.e., yes/no) and as a continuous variable (i.e., total number of days), and will be determined by independent, blinded behavioral health personnel.

secondary_outcome.description: The BSSI is used to evaluate the intensity of the patient's specific attitudes, behaviors, and plans to make a suicide attempt.

The RFL task is a timed procedure in which the participant is asked to verbally list as many reasons for living as they can. Response latency is the primary variable of interest in this task, and is measured as the length of time it takes from initiation of the task (i.e., reading the instructions) to the verbalization of the first reason for living. Response latency will be measured and coded by independent raters who view the recorded interventions.

Ambivalence about suicide will be measured using Item 1 (Wish to Live) and Item 2 (Wish to Die) of the Beck Scale for Suicide Ideation-Current (SSI-C, described above). The value of Item 1 will first be reverse-scored so that a high score (2) indicates a strong wish to live. The value of Item 2 will remain unadjusted since a high score (2) indicate a strong wish to die. Next, the reverse-scored Item 1 will be subtracted from the unadjusted value of Item 2 to calculate an ambivalence score ranging from -2 (strong wish to live) to +2 (strong wish to die), with scores in the middle of this range indicating the simultaneous presence of both the desire to live and to die (ambivalence). This method of calculating suicidal ambivalence has been found to significantly predict future death by suicide.
The 20-item SIS is used to assess the intensity of an individual's wish to die at the time of an index suicide attempt.

The 4-item SBQ-R is used to screen for four dimensions of suicidality: lifetime suicidal ideation, suicidal ideation frequency during the past year, suicide attempt history, and the self-reported likelihood of a suicide attempt in the future.

The 4-item DSI is a brief self-report measure of suicidal ideation that that assesses frequency of suicidal ideation, suicidal planning, perceived control over suicidal ideation, and intensity of the urge for suicide.
The 21-item BDI-II is a self-report instrument developed to measure severity of depression in adults and adolescents.
The 17-item PCL assesses the severity of each DSM-IV-defined PTSD symptoms.
The 20-item BHS consists of true-false statements designed to assess the extent of positive and negative beliefs about the future.
The 16-item ASI measures the degree to which respondents fear anxiety symptoms on a 5-point Likert rating scale.

other_outcome.description: The 18-item SCS-R measures two aspects of suicide-specific hopelessness: 1) unlovability (i.e., trait hopelessness), and 2) unbearability (i.e., state hopelessness).

The INQ is a 15-item self-report questionnaire that measures current beliefs about the extent to which the respondent feels connected to others (i.e., thwarted belongingness), and the extent to which he or she feels like a burden on the people in their lives (i.e., perceived burdensomeness).
The 10-item LOT-R is a brief measure of general optimism that has been widely used in research. Internal consistency is good (> .82), and factor analyses have supported the single-factor solution.
The 10-item MLQ measures two dimensions of perceived purpose in life: current sense of purpose and meaning, and active engagement in pursuing a sense of purpose and meaning.
The PFQ2 is a 16-item self-report instrument designed to measure guilt and shame.

The ISI is a 7-item index of insomnia severity using a 5-point scale that measures perceived severity of problems with sleep onset, sleep maintenance, and early morning awakenings; dissatisfaction with current sleep patterns; extent of interference with daily functioning; noticeable impairment in functioning; and extent of worry and anxiety associated with sleep patterns.
The 22-item RSES is a self-report scale developed by the National Center for PTSD to measure several dimensions of resilient behaviors and processes.

The VAMS measures internal mood states using vertical lines of standardized length (e.g., 100 mm), with one end corresponding to an absence of the mood state and the other end corresponding to a very severe or intense level of the mood state.
This clinician-administered interview assesses for the frequency of visits to various medical specialties (including mental health services) both within and external to the military medical system.

The WAI is a 12-item measure that assesses three aspects of the therapeutic relationship: (a) the bond between patient and therapist, (b) the extent to which the patient and therapist agree on the goals of treatment, and (c) the extent to which the patient and therapist see the tasks of therapy as relevant.

arm_group.description: TAU includes the following intervention components: suicide risk assessment supportive listening provision of professional and crisis contact information referral to mental health treatment and community resources

CRP includes the following intervention components: suicide risk assessment supportive listening identify personal warning signs identify self-management skills identify social support contacts provision of professional and crisis contact information referral to mental health treatment and community resources

The E-CRP includes the following intervention components: suicide risk assessment supportive listening identify personal warning signs identify self-management skills identify reasons for living identify social support contacts provision of professional and crisis contact information referral to mental health treatment and community resources

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Active duty
- 18 years of age or older
- Reporting current suicidal ideation with intent to die, or a suicide attempt within the past two weeks
- Able to speak and understand the English language
- Able to complete the informed consent process
Exclusion Criteria:
- Severe psychiatric or medical conditions that preclude the ability to provide informed consent or participation in outpatient treatment
